Substance Use Diagnosis Ontology
An observable state that is characterizing the use, or lack thereof, of a chemical compound with psychoactive properties.
A substance use phenotype in which a substance is used. Use may be through inhalation, injection, ingestion or other means by which the substance may enter the body.
A type of substance use phenotype in which there is no knowledge or evidence for any use of a substance.
A type of substance use phenotype in which there is no knowledge or evidence for a substance use disorder.
A type of substance use phenotype in which there has been substance use in the past, but there is no evidence or knowledge of any current substance use.
A type of substance use characterized by isolated or sporadic use of significant quantities of a substance in a short time period.
A type of substance use characterized by occasional limited use of a substance, without adverse consequences or behavioral/physiologic symptoms of a substance use disorder.

A type of substance use in which the use of the substance is frequent and persistent for a period of 3 months or greater; may or may not be accompanied by behavioral or physiologic symptoms necessary to define a substance use disorder.
A substance use phenotype in which alcohol is used. Use may be through inhalation, injection, ingestion or other means by which the substance may enter the body.
A type of alcohol use characterized by isolated or sporadic use of significant quantities of alcohol in a short time period.
A type of alcohol use characterized by occasional limited use of alcohol, without adverse consequences or behavioral/physiologic symptoms of a substance use disorder.

A type of alcohol use in which the use of alcohol is frequent and persistent for a period of 3 months or greater; may or may not be accompanied by behavioral or physiologic symptoms necessary to define a substance use disorder.
A type of chronic alcohol use where there is continued use of alcohol despite harm or adverse consequence to self or others. This is defined by behavioral criteria and physiologic symptoms.
A type of alcohol use in which the amounts or methods of use of alcohol are harmful or problematic to the individual or others (also called alcohol misuse)
DSM_IV

A maladaptive pattern of alcohol use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, as manifested by one (or more) of the following, occurring within a 12-month period: 1) Recurrent alcohol use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligation at work, school, or home; 2) Recurrent alcohol use in situations in which it is physically hazardous; 3) Recurrent alcohol-related legal problems; 4) Continued alcohol use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of alcohol.
DSM_IV
A type of alcohol use in which the use of alcohol is compulsive and repetitive and may result in tolerance to the effect of the drug and withdrawal symptoms when use is reduced or stopped.

A pattern of alcohol use, leading to impairment or distress, as manifested by one to two of the following, occurring at any time in the same 12-month period: 1) Tolerance, as defined by either the following: a. Need for markedly increased amounts of alcohol to achieve intoxication or desired effect. b. Markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount of alcohol; 2) Withdrawal, as manifested by either of the following: a. The characteristic withdrawal syndrome for alcohol. b. The same (or closely related) substance is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms; 3) alcohol is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended; 4) There is persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control alcohol use; 5) A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain alcohol, use alcohol or recover from its effects; 6) Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of alcohol use; 7) alcohol use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by alcohol.
DSM_IV

A maladaptive pattern of alcohol use, leading to significant impairment or distress, as manifested by three (or more) of the following, occurring at any time in the same 12-month period: 1) Tolerance, as defined by either the following: a. Need for markedly increased amounts of alcohol to achieve intoxication or desired effect. b. Markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount of alcohol; 2) Withdrawal, as manifested by either of the following: a. The characteristic withdrawal syndrome for alcohol. b. The same (or closely related) substance is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms; 3) alcohol is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended; 4) There is persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control alcohol use; 5) A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain alcohol, use alcohol or recover from its effects; 6) Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of alcohol use; 7) alcohol use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by alcohol.
DSM_IV

A problematic pattern of alcohol use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, as manifested by two of the following, occurring within a 12-month period: 1) alcohol is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended; 2) There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control alcohol use; 3) A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain alcohol, use alcohol, or recover from its effects; 4) Craving, or a strong desire or urge to use alcohol; 5) Recurrent alcohol use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home; 6) Continued alcohol use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of alcohol; 7) Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of alcohol use; 8) Recurrent alcohol use in situations in which it is physically hazardous; 9) alcohol use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by alcohol; 10) Tolerance, as defined by either of the following:a.
